MCMC pipelines

Source: vignettes/mcmc.Rmd
mcmc.Rmd

The stantargets package makes it easy to run a single Stan model and keep track of the results. cmdstanr fits the models, and targets manages the workflow and helps avoid unnecessary computation.

First, write a Stan model file.

lines <- "data {
  int <lower = 1> n;
  vector[n] x;
  vector[n] y;
  real true_beta;
}
parameters {
  real beta;
}
model {
  y ~ normal(x * beta, 1);
  beta ~ normal(0, 1);
}"
writeLines(lines, "stantargets_example.stan")

Next, create a _targets.R file to define the targets pipeline.

library(targets)
tar_script({
  library(stantargets)
  options(crayon.enabled = FALSE)
  tar_option_set(memory = "transient", garbage_collection = TRUE)
  tar_pipeline(
    tar_stan_mcmc(
      example,
      "stantargets_example.stan",
      tar_stan_example_data(),
      refresh = 0,
      init = 1,
      show_messages = FALSE
    )
  )
})

tar_stan_mcmc(example, ...) defines several targets:

  • example_file: Reproducibly track changes to the Stan model file.
  • example_data: Run the code you supplied to data and return a dataset compatible with Stan.
  • example_mcmc: Run the MCMC and return an object of class CmdStanMCMC.
  • example_draws: Return a friendly tibble of the posterior draws from example. Uses the $draws() method. Suppress with draws = FALSE in tar_stan_mcmc().
  • example_summaries: Return a friendly tibble of the posterior summaries from example. Uses the $summary() method. Suppress with summary = FALSE in tar_stan_mcmc().
  • example_diagnostics: Return a friendly tibble of the sampler diagnostics from example. Uses the $sampler_diagnostics() method. Suppress with diagnostics = FALSE in tar_stan_mcmc().
tar_manifest()
#> # A tibble: 6 x 3
#>   name            command                                                pattern
#>   <chr>           <chr>                                                  <chr>  
#> 1 example_draws   "tibble::as_tibble(posterior::as_draws_df(example_mcm… <NA>   
#> 2 example_mcmc    "stantargets::tar_stan_mcmc_run(file = example_file, … <NA>   
#> 3 example_summary "example_mcmc$summary(variables = identity(NULL), .ar… <NA>   
#> 4 example_data    "tar_stan_example_data()"                              <NA>   
#> 5 example_file    "\"stantargets_example.stan\""                         <NA>   
#> 6 example_diagno… "tibble::as_tibble(posterior::as_draws_df(example_mcm… <NA>

targets produces a graph to show the dependency relationships among the targets. Below, the MCMC depends on the model file and the data, and the draws, summary, and diagnostics depend on the MCMC.

tar_visnetwork(targets_only = TRUE)

Run the computation with tar_make().

tar_make()
#> ● run target example_data
#> ● run target example_file
#> ● run target example_mcmc
#> Compiling Stan program...
#> Running MCMC with 4 sequential chains...
#> 
#> Chain 1 finished in 0.0 seconds.
#> Chain 2 finished in 0.0 seconds.
#> Chain 3 finished in 0.0 seconds.
#> Chain 4 finished in 0.0 seconds.
#> 
#> All 4 chains finished successfully.
#> Mean chain execution time: 0.0 seconds.
#> Total execution time: 0.9 seconds.
#> ● run target example_draws
#> ● run target example_summary
#> ● run target example_diagnostics

The output lives in a special folder called _targets/ and you can retrieve it with functions tar_load() and tar_read() (from targets).

tar_read(example_summary)
#> # A tibble: 2 x 10
#>   variable   mean median    sd   mad     q5    q95  rhat ess_bulk ess_tail
#>   <chr>     <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl>    <dbl>    <dbl>
#> 1 lp__     -5.85  -5.59  0.691 0.309 -7.20  -5.37   1.00    1904.    2286.
#> 2 beta     -0.150 -0.157 0.436 0.441 -0.857  0.565  1.00    1394.    1829.

At this point, all our results are up to date because their dependencies did not change.

tar_make()
#> ✔ skip target example_data
#> ✔ skip target example_file
#> ✔ skip target example_mcmc
#> ✔ skip target example_draws
#> ✔ skip target example_summary
#> ✔ skip target example_diagnostics
#> ✔ Already up to date.

But if we change the underlying code or data, some of the targets will no longer be valid, and they will rerun during the next tar_make(). Below, we change the Stan model file, so the MCMC reruns while the data is skipped. This behavior saves time and enhances reproducibility.

write(" ", file = "stantargets_example.stan", append = TRUE)
tar_outdated()
#> [1] "example_draws"       "example_mcmc"        "example_summary"    
#> [4] "example_file"        "example_diagnostics"
tar_visnetwork(targets_only = TRUE)
tar_make()
#> ✔ skip target example_data
#> ● run target example_file
#> ● run target example_mcmc
#> Compiling Stan program...
#> Running MCMC with 4 sequential chains...
#> 
#> Chain 1 finished in 0.0 seconds.
#> Chain 2 finished in 0.0 seconds.
#> Chain 3 finished in 0.0 seconds.
#> Chain 4 finished in 0.0 seconds.
#> 
#> All 4 chains finished successfully.
#> Mean chain execution time: 0.0 seconds.
#> Total execution time: 0.7 seconds.
#> ● run target example_draws
#> ● run target example_summary
#> ● run target example_diagnostics

At this point, we can add more targets and custom functions for additional post-processing.

library(targets)
tar_script({
  library(stantargets)
  options(crayon.enabled = FALSE)
  tar_option_set(memory = "transient", garbage_collection = TRUE)
  tar_pipeline(
    tar_stan_mcmc(
      example,
      "stantargets_example.stan",
      tar_stan_example_data(),
      refresh = 0,
      init = 1,
      show_messages = FALSE
    ),
    tar_stan_summary(
      custom_summary,
      fit = example_mcmc,
      summaries = list(~posterior::quantile2(.x, probs = c(0.25, 0.75)))
    )
  )
})

In the graph, our new custom_summary target should be connected to the upstream example target, and only custom_summary should be out of date.

tar_visnetwork(targets_only = TRUE)

In the next tar_make(), we skip the expensive MCMC and just run the custom summary.

tar_make()
#> ✔ skip target example_data
#> ✔ skip target example_file
#> ✔ skip target example_mcmc
#> ✔ skip target example_draws
#> ✔ skip target example_summary
#> ● run target custom_summary
#> ✔ skip target example_diagnostics
tar_read(custom_summary)
#> # A tibble: 2 x 3
#>   variable    q25    q75
#>   <chr>     <dbl>  <dbl>
#> 1 lp__     -6.01  -5.41 
#> 2 beta     -0.444  0.152

For more on targets, please visit the reference website https://wlandau.github.io/targets/ or the user manual https://wlandau.github.io/targets-manual/. The manual walks though advanced features of targets such as high-performance computing and cloud storage support.

Developed by William Michael Landau.
